org.apache.juneau.rest.client2

Class RestClient

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.juneau.Context
      • org.apache.juneau.BeanContext
        • org.apache.juneau.rest.client2.RestClient
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Closeable, AutoCloseable, HttpClient, MetaProvider

    @ConfigurableContext(nocache=true)
public class RestClient
extends BeanContext
implements HttpClient, Closeable
    Utility class for interfacing with remote REST interfaces.

    Built upon the feature-rich Apache HttpClient library, the Juneau RestClient API adds support for fluent-style REST calls and the ability to perform marshalling of POJOs to and from HTTP parts.

    Example:

    // Create a basic REST client with JSON support and download a bean. try (RestClient c = RestClient.create().build()) { MyBean b = c.get(URL).run().assertStatusCode(200).getBody().as(MyBean.class); }

    Breaking apart the fluent call, we can see the classes being used:

    // Create a basic REST client with JSON support and download a bean. try (RestClient c = RestClient.create().build()) { RestRequest req = c.get(URL); RestResponse res = req.run(); res.assertStatusCode(200); RestResponseBody body = res.getBody(); MyBean b = body.as(MyBean.class); }

    It additionally provides support for creating remote proxy interfaces using REST as the transport medium.

    Example:

    // Define a Remote proxy for interacting with a REST interface. @Remote(path="/petstore") public interface PetStore { @RemoteMethod(httpMethod=POST, path="/pets") Pet addPet( @Body CreatePet pet, @Header("E-Tag") UUID etag, @Query("debug") boolean debug ); } // Use a RestClient with default Simple JSON support. try (RestClient c = RestClient.create().simpleJson().build()) { PetStore store = c.getRemote(PetStore.class, "http://localhost:10000"); CreatePet cp = new CreatePet("Fluffy", 9.99); Pet p = store.addPet(cp, UUID.randomUUID(), true); }

    The classes are closely tied to Apache HttpClient, yet provide lots of additional functionality:

    • RestClient extends HttpClient, creates RestRequest objects.
    • RestRequest extends HttpUriRequest, creates RestResponse objects.
    • RestResponse extends HttpResponse, creates RestResponseBody and RestResponseHeader objects.
    • RestResponseBody extends HttpEntity
    • RestResponseHeader extends Header

    Instantiation and Lifecycle

    Instances of this class are built using the RestClientBuilder class which can be constructed using the RestClient.create() method as shown above.

    Clients are typically created with a root URL so that relative URLs can be used when making requests. This is done using the RestClientBuilder.rootUrl(Object) method.

    Example:

    // Create a client where all URLs are relative to localhost. RestClient c = RestClient.create().rootUrl("http://localhost:5000").build(); // Use relative paths. String body = c.get("/subpath").run().getBody().asString();

    The RestClient class creates RestRequest objects using the following methods:

    • RestClient
      • get(Object url)
      • put(Object url, Object body)
      • put(Object url)
      • post(Object url, Object body)
      • post(Object url)
      • patch(Object url, Object body)
      • patch(Object url)
      • delete(Object url)
      • options(Object url)
      • formPost(Object url, Object body)
      • formPost(Object url)
      • formPost(Object url, NameValuePairs parameters)
      • formPost(Object url, NameValuePair...parameters)
      • formPost(Object url, Object...parameters)
      • request(HttpMethod method, Object url, Object body)

    The RestRequest class creates RestResponse objects using the following methods:

    • RestRequest
      • run()
      • complete()

    The distinction between the two methods is that complete() automatically consumes the response body and run() does not. Note that you must consume response bodies in order for HTTP connections to be freed up for reuse! The InputStreams returned by the RestResponseBody object are auto-closing once they are exhausted, so it is often not necessary to explicitly close them.

    The following examples show the distinction between the two calls:

    // Consuming the response, so use run(). String body = client.get(URL).run().getBody().asString(); // Only interested in response status code, so use complete(). int status = client.get(URL).complete().getStatusCode();

    POJO Marshalling

    By default, JSON support is provided for HTTP request and response bodies. Other languages can be specified using any of the following builder methods:

    • RestClientBuilder
      • json()
      • simpleJson()
      • xml()
      • html()
      • plainText()
      • msgpack()
      • uon()
      • urlEnc()
      • openapi()
    Example:

    // Create a basic REST client with Simplified-JSON support. // Typically easier to use when performing unit tests. RestClient c = RestClient.create().simpleJson().build();

    Other methods are also provided for specifying the serializers and parsers used for lower-level marshalling support:

    • RestClientBuilder
      • serializer(Serializer)
      • serializer(Class<? extends Serializer>)
      • parser(Parser)
      • parser(Class<? extends Parser>)
      • marshall(Marshall)

    HTTP parts (headers, query parameters, form data...) are serialized and parsed using the HttpPartSerializer and HttpPartParser APIs. By default, clients are configured to use OpenApiSerializer and OpenApiParser. These can be overridden using the following methods:

    • RestClientBuilder
      • partSerializer(HttpPartSerializer)
      • partSerializer(Class<? extends HttpPartSerializer>)
      • partParser(HttpPartParser)
      • partParser(Class<? extends HttpPartParser>)

    The RestClientBuilder class also provides convenience methods for setting common serializer and parser settings.

    Example:

    // Create a basic REST client with JSON support. // Use single-quotes and whitespace. RestClient c = RestClient.create().json().sq().ws().build();

    Request Headers

    Per-client or per-request headers can be specified using the following methods:

    • RestClientBuilder
      • header(Header)
      • header(HttpHeader)
      • header(NameValuePair)
      • header(String,Object)
      • header(String,Object,HttpPartSerializer,HttpPartSchema)
      • headers(Header...)
      • headers(HttpHeader...)
      • headers(Map<String,Object>)
      • headers(NameValuePair...)
      • headers(NameValuePairs)
      • headers(Object...)
      • headers(ObjectMap)
      • accept(Object)
      • acceptCharset(Object)
      • acceptEncoding(Object)
      • acceptLanguage(Object)
      • authorization(Object)
      • cacheControl(Object)
      • clientVersion(Object)
      • connection(Object)
      • contentLength(Object)
      • contentType(Object)
      • date(Object)
      • expect(Object)
      • forwarded(Object)
      • from(Object)
      • host(Object)
      • ifMatch(Object)
      • ifModifiedSince(Object)
      • ifNoneMatch(Object)
      • ifRange(Object)
      • ifUnmodifiedSince(Object)
      • maxForwards(Object)
      • origin(Object)
      • pragma(Object)
      • proxyAuthorization(Object)
      • proxyAuthorization(Object)
      • referer(Object)
      • te(Object)
      • userAgent(Object)
      • upgrade(Object)
      • via(Object)
      • warning(Object)
    • RestRequest
      • header(Header)
      • header(Header,boolean)
      • header(HttpHeader)
      • header(NameValuePair)
      • header(NameValuePair,boolean)
      • header(String,Object)
      • header(String,Object,boolean,HttpPartSerializer,HttpPartSchema)
      • headers(Header...)
      • headers(HttpHeader...)
      • headers(Map<String,Object>)
      • headers(NameValuePair...)
      • headers(NameValuePairs)
      • headers(Object)
      • headers(Object...)
      • headers(ObjectMap)
      • accept(Object)
      • acceptCharset(Object)
      • acceptEncoding(Object)
      • acceptLanguage(Object)
      • authorization(Object)
      • cacheControl(Object)
      • clientVersion(Object)
      • connection(Object)
      • contentLength(Object)
      • contentType(Object)
      • date(Object)
      • expect(Object)
      • forwarded(Object)
      • from(Object)
      • host(Object)
      • ifMatch(Object)
      • ifModifiedSince(Object)
      • ifNoneMatch(Object)
      • ifRange(Object)
      • ifUnmodifiedSince(Object)
      • maxForwards(Object)
      • origin(Object)
      • pragma(Object)
      • proxyAuthorization(Object)
      • proxyAuthorization(Object)
      • referer(Object)
      • te(Object)
      • userAgent(Object)
      • upgrade(Object)
      • via(Object)
      • warning(Object)
    Example:

    // Create a client that adds an Authorization header to every request. RestClient c = RestClient.create().header("Authorization", "Foo").build(); // Or do it on every request. String response = c.get(URL).authorization("Foo").run().getBody().asString(); // Or use an HttpHeader. response = c.get(URL).headers(new Authorization("Foo")).run().getBody().asString();

    Note that in the methods above, header values are specified as objects which are converted to strings at runtime. This allows you to pass in headers whose values may change over time (such as Authorization headers which may need to change every few minutes).

    Example:

    public class AuthGenerator { public String toString() { // Generate an updated auth token. } } // Create a client that adds an Authorization header to every request. RestClient c = RestClient.create().authorization(new AuthGenerator()).build();

    • Methods that pass in POJOs convert values to strings using the part serializers. Methods that pass in Header or NameValuePair objects use the values returned by that bean directly.

    Request Query Parameters

    Per-client or per-request query parmameters can be specified using the following methods:

    • RestClientBuilder
      • query(Map<String,Object>)
      • query(NameValuePair)
      • query(NameValuePair...)
      • query(NameValuePairs)
      • query(Object...)
      • query(ObjectMap)
      • query(String,Object)
      • query(String,Object,HttpPartSerializer,HttpPartSchema)
    • RestRequest
      • query(Map<String,Object>)
      • query(NameValuePair)
      • query(NameValuePair,boolean)
      • query(NameValuePair...)
      • query(NameValuePairs)
      • query(Object)
      • query(Object...)
      • query(ObjectMap)
      • query(String)
      • query(String,Object)
      • query(String,Object,boolean,HttpPartSerializer,HttpPartSchema)
    Example:

    // Create a client that adds a ?foo=bar query parameter to every request. RestClient c = RestClient.create().query("foo", "bar").build(); // Or do it on every request. String response = c.get(URL).query("foo", "bar").run().getBody().asString();

    • Like header values, you can pass in objects that get converted to strings at runtime.
    • Methods that pass in POJOs convert values to strings using the part serializers. Methods that pass in NameValuePair objects use the values returned by that bean directly.

    Request Form Data

    Per-client or per-request form-data parameters can be specified using the following methods:

    • RestClientBuilder
      • formData(Map<String,Object>)
      • formData(NameValuePair)
      • formData(NameValuePair...)
      • formData(NameValuePairs)
      • formData(Object...)
      • formData(ObjectMap)
      • formData(String,Object)
      • formData(String,Object,HttpPartSerializer,HttpPartSchema)
    • RestRequest
      • formData(CharSequence)
      • formData(InputStream)
      • formData(Map<String,Object>)
      • formData(NameValuePair)
      • formData(NameValuePair,boolean)
      • formData(NameValuePair...)
      • formData(NameValuePairs)
      • formData(Object)
      • formData(Object...)
      • formData(ObjectMap)
      • formData(Reader)
      • formData(String,Object)
      • formData(String,Object,boolean,HttpPartSerializer,HttpPartSchema)
    • Like header values, you can pass in objects that get converted to strings at runtime.
    • Methods that pass in POJOs convert values to strings using the part serializers. Methods that pass in NameValuePair objects use the values returned by that bean directly.

    Request Body

    The request body can either be passed in with the client creator method (e.g. post(Object,Object)), or can be specified via the following methods:

    • RestRequest
      • body(Object)
      • body(Object,HttpPartSchema)

    The request body can be any of the following types:

    • Object - POJO to be converted to text using the Serializer defined on the client or request.
    • Reader - Raw contents of Reader will be serialized to remote resource.
    • InputStream - Raw contents of InputStream will be serialized to remote resource.
    • ReaderResource - Raw contents of Reader will be serialized to remote resource. Additional headers and media type will be set on request.
    • StreamResource - Raw contents of InputStream will be serialized to remote resource. Additional headers and media type will be set on request.
    • HttpEntity - Bypass Juneau serialization and pass HttpEntity directly to HttpClient.
    • NameValuePairs - Converted to a URL-encoded FORM post.
    • If the serializer on the client or request is explicitly set to null, POJOs will be converted to strings using the registered part serializer as content type "text/plain. If the part serializer is also null, POJOs will be converted to strings using ClassMeta.toString(Object) which typically just calls Object.toString().

    Response Status

    After execution using RestRequest.run() or RestRequest.complete(), the following methods can be used to get the response status:

    • RestResponse
      • getStatusLine() returns StatusLine
      • getStatusLine(Mutable<StatusLine>) returns RestResponse
      • getStatusCode() returns int
      • getStatusCode(Mutable<Integer>) returns RestResponse
      • getReasonPhrase() returns String
      • getReasonPhrase(Mutable<String>) returns RestResponse
      • assertStatusCode(int...) returns RestResponse
      • assertStatusCode(Predicate<Integer>) returns RestResponse

    The methods with mutable parameters are provided to allow access to status values without breaking fluent call chains.

    Example:

    // Only interested in status code. int statusCode = c.get(URL).complete().getStatusCode(); // Interested in multiple values. Mutable<Integer> statusCode; Mutable<String> reasonPhrase; c.get(URL).complete().getStatusCode(statusCode).getReasonPhrase(reasonPhrase); System.err.println("statusCode="+statusCode.get()+", reasonPhrase="+reasonPhrase.get());

    • If you are only interested in the response status and not the response body, be sure to use RestRequest.complete() instead of RestRequest.run() to make sure the response body gets automatically cleaned up. Otherwise you must consume the response yourself.

    The assertion methods are provided for quickly asserting status codes in fluent calls.

    Example:

    // Status assertion using a static value. String body = c.get(URL).run().assertStatusCode(200).getBody().asString(); // Status assertion using a predicate. String body = c.get(URL).run().assertStatusCode(x -> x < 400).getBody().asString();

    Response Headers

    Response headers are accessed through the following methods:

    • RestResponse
      • getHeader(String) returns RestResponseHeader
      • getHeaders(String) returns RestResponseHeader[]
      • getFirstHeader(String) returns RestResponseHeader
      • getLastHeader(String) returns RestResponseHeader
      • getAllHeaders() returns RestResponseHeader[]
      • getStringHeader(String) returns String
      • getStringHeader(String,String) returns String
      • containsHeader(String) returns boolean

    Unlike RestResponse.getFirstHeader(String) and RestResponse.getLastHeader(String), the RestResponse.getHeader(String) method returns an empty RestResponseHeader object instead of returning null. This allows it to be used more easily in fluent calls.

    Example:

    // See if response contains Location header. boolean hasLocationHeader = c.get(URL).complete().getHeader("Location").exists();

    The RestResponseHeader class extends from the HttpClient Header class and provides several convenience methods:

    • RestResponseHeader
      • exists() returns boolean
      • asString() returns String
      • asString(Mutable<String>) returns RestResponse
      • asOptionalString() returns Optional<String>
      • asStringOrElse(String) returns String
      • asStringOrElse(Mutable<String>,String) returns RestResponse
      • as(Type,Type...) returns T
      • as(Mutable<T>,Type,Type...) returns RestResponse
      • as(Class<T>) returnsT
      • as(Mutable<T>,Class<T>) returns RestResponse
      • as(ClassMeta<T>) returns T
      • as(Mutable<T>,ClassMeta<T>) returns RestResponse
      • asOptional(Type,Type...) returns Optional<T>
      • asOptional(Mutable<Optional<T>>,Type,Type...) returns RestResponse
      • asOptional(Class<T>) returns Optional<T>
      • asOptional(Mutable<Optional<T>>,Class<T>) returns RestResponse
      • asOptional(ClassMeta<T>) returns Optional<T>
      • asOptional(Mutable<Optional<T>>,ClassMeta<T>) returns RestResponse
      • asMatcher(Pattern) returns Matcher
      • asMatcher(Mutable<Matcher>,Pattern) returns RestResponse
      • asMatcher(String) returns Matcher
      • asMatcher(Mutable<Matcher>,String) returns RestResponse
      • asMatcher(String,int) returns Matcher
      • asMatcher(Mutable<Matcher>,String,int) returns RestResponse
      • assertExists() returns RestResponse
      • assertValue(String) returns RestResponse
      • assertValue(Predicate<String>) returns RestResponse
      • assertValueContains(String...) returns RestResponse
      • assertValueMatches(String) returns RestResponse
      • assertValueMatches(String,int) returns RestResponse
      • assertValueMatches(Pattern) returns RestResponse

    Response Body

    The response body is accessed through the following method:

    • RestResponse
      • getBody() returns RestResponseBody

    The RestResponseBody class extends from the HttpClient HttpEntity class and provides several convenience methods:

    • RestResponseBody
      • asInputStream() returns InputStream
      • asReader() returns Reader
      • asReader(String) returns Reader
      • pipeTo(OutputStream) returns RestResponse
      • pipeTo(Writer) returns RestResponse
      • pipeTo(Writer,String) returns RestResponse
      • pipeTo(Writer,boolean) returns RestResponse
      • pipeTo(Writer,String,boolean) returns RestResponse
      • as(Type,Type...) returns T
      • as(Mutable<T>,Type,Type...) returns RestResponse
      • as(Class<T>) returns T
      • as(Mutable<T>,Class<T>) returns RestResponse
      • as(ClassMeta<T>) returns T
      • as(Mutable<T>,ClassMeta<T>) returns RestResponse
      • asFuture(Class<T>) returns Future<T>
      • asFuture(Mutable<Future<T>>,Class<T>) returns RestResponse
      • asFuture(ClassMeta<T>) returnsFuture<T>
      • asFuture(Mutable<Future<T>>,ClassMeta<T>) returns RestResponse
      • asFuture(Type,Type...) returns Future<T>
      • asFuture(Mutable<Future<T>>,Type,Type...) returns RestResponse
      • asString() returns String
      • asString(Mutable<String>) returns RestResponse
      • asStringFuture() returns Future<String>
      • asStringFuture(Mutable<Future<String>>) returns RestResponse
      • asAbbreviatedString(int) returns String
      • asAbbreviatedString(Mutable<String>,int) returns RestResponse
      • asPojoRest(Class<?>) returns PojoRest
      • asPojoRest(Mutable<PojoRest>,Class<?>) returns RestResponse
      • asPojoRest() returns PojoRest
      • asPojoRest(Mutable<PojoRest>) returns RestResponse
      • asMatcher(Pattern) returns Matcher
      • asMatcher(Mutable<Matcher>,Pattern) returns RestResponse
      • asMatcher(String) returns Matcher
      • asMatcher(Mutable<Matcher>,String) returns RestResponse
      • asMatcher(String,int) returns Matcher
      • asMatcher(Mutable<Matcher>,String,int) returns RestResponse
      • assertValue(String) returns RestResponse
      • assertValueContains(String...) returns RestResponse
      • assertValue(Predicate<String>) returns RestResponse
      • assertValueMatches(String) returns RestResponse
      • assertValueMatches(String,int) returns RestResponse
      • assertValueMatches(Pattern) returns RestResponse
    Examples:

    // Parse into a linked-list of strings. List<String> l = client.get(URL).run() .getBody().as(LinkedList.class, String.class); // Parse into a linked-list of beans. List<MyBean> l = client.get(URL).run() .getBody().as(LinkedList.class, MyBean.class); // Parse into a linked-list of linked-lists of strings. List<List<String>> l = client.get(URL).run() .getBody().as(LinkedList.class, LinkedList.class, String.class); // Parse into a map of string keys/values. Map<String,String> m = client.get(URL).run() .getBody().as(TreeMap.class, String.class, String.class); // Parse into a map containing string keys and values of lists containing beans. Map<String,List<MyBean>> m = client.get(URL).run() .getBody().as(TreeMap.class, String.class, List.class, MyBean.class);

    The response body can only be consumed once. However, the RestResponseBody.cache() method is provided to cache the response body in memory so that you can perform several operations against it.

    Examples:

    // Cache the response body so that you can perform multiple operations against it. String body = client.get(URL).run() .getBody().cache().assertValueContains("Success") .getBody().asString();

    Customizing Apache HttpClient

    Several methods are provided for customizing the underlying HTTP client and client builder classes:

    • RestClientBuilder
      • getHttpClientBuilder()
      • httpClientBuilder(HttpClientBuilder)
      • createHttpClientBuilder()
      • createHttpClient()
      • createConnectionManager()
      • pooled()

    Additionally, all methods on the HttpClientBuilder class are also exposed with fluent setters:

    • RestClientBuilder
      • disableRedirectHandling()
      • redirectStrategy(RedirectStrategy)
      • defaultCookieSpecRegistry(Lookup<CookieSpecProvider>)
      • requestExecutor(HttpRequestExecutor)
      • sslHostnameVerifier(HostnameVerifier)

      • sslContext(SSLContext)
      • sslSocketFactory(LayeredConnectionSocketFactory)

      • defaultConnectionConfig(ConnectionConfig)
      • connectionTimeToLive(long,TimeUnit)
      • connectionManager(HttpClientConnectionManager)

      • keepAliveStrategy(ConnectionKeepAliveStrategy)
      • targetAuthenticationStrategy(AuthenticationStrategy)
      • proxyAuthenticationStrategy(AuthenticationStrategy)
      • userTokenHandler(UserTokenHandler)
      • disableConnectionState()
      • schemePortResolver(SchemePortResolver)
      • userAgent(String)
      • defaultHeaders(Collection<? extends Header>)
      • addInterceptorFirst(HttpResponseInterceptor)
      • addInterceptorLast(HttpResponseInterceptor)
      • addInterceptorFirst(HttpRequestInterceptor)
      • addInterceptorLast(HttpRequestInterceptor)
      • disableCookieManagement()

      • contentDecoderRegistry(Map<String,InputStreamFactory>)
      • defaultRequestConfig(RequestConfig)
      • useSystemProperties()
      • evictExpiredConnections()
      • evictIdleConnections(long,TimeUnit)

    Custom Call Handlers

    The RestCallHandler interface provides the ability to provide custom handling of requests.

    • RestClientBuilder
      • callHandler(Class<? extends RestCallHandler>)
      • callHandler(RestCallHandler)
    • RestCallHandler
      • execute(HttpHost,HttpEntityEnclosingRequestBase,HttpContext) returns HttpResponse
      • execute(HttpHost,HttpRequestBase,HttpContext) returns HttpResponse

    Note that there are other ways of accomplishing this such as extending the RestClient class and overriding the execute(HttpHost,HttpEntityEnclosingRequestBase,HttpContext) and execute(HttpHost,HttpRequestBase,HttpContext) or by defining your own HttpRequestExecutor. Using this interface is often simpler though.

    Logging / Debugging

    The following methods provide logging of requests and responses:

    • RestClientBuilder
      • logTo(Level,Logger)
      • logToConsole()
    • RestRequest
      • logTo(Level,Logger)
      • logToConsole()

    It should be noted that if you enable logging, response bodies will be cached by default which may introduce a performance penalty.

    Additionally, the following method is also provided for enabling debug mode:

    • RestClientBuilder
      • debug()

    Enabling debug mode has the following effects:

    • BeanContext.BEAN_debug is enabled.
    • RESTCLIENT_leakDetection is enabled.
    • RestClientBuilder.logToConsole() is called.

    Interceptors

    The RestCallInterceptor API provides a quick way of intercepting and manipulating requests and responses.

    • RestClientBuilder
      • interceptors(RestCallInterceptor...)
    • RestRequest
      • interceptors(RestCallInterceptor...)
    • RestCallInterceptor
      • onInit(RestRequest)
      • onConnect(RestRequest,RestResponse)
      • onClose(RestRequest,RestResponse)

    Note that the HttpRequestInterceptor and HttpResponseInterceptor classes can also be used for intercepting requests.

    REST Proxies

    One of the more powerful features of the REST client class is the ability to produce Java interface proxies against arbitrary remote REST resources.

    Example:

    // Define a Remote proxy for interacting with a REST interface. @Remote(path="/petstore") public interface PetStore { @RemoteMethod(httpMethod=POST, path="/pets") Pet addPet( @Body CreatePet pet, @Header("E-Tag") UUID etag, @Query("debug") boolean debug ); } // Use a RestClient with default Simple JSON support. try (RestClient c = RestClient.create().simpleJson().build()) { PetStore store = c.getRemote(PetStore.class, "http://localhost:10000"); CreatePet cp = new CreatePet("Fluffy", 9.99); Pet p = store.addPet(cp, UUID.randomUUID(), true); }

    The methods to retrieve remote interfaces are:

    • RestClient
      • getRemote(Class<T>) returns T
      • getRemote(Class<T>,Object) returns T
      • getRemote(Class<T>,Object,Serializer,Parser) returns T
      • getRrpcInterface(Class<T>) returns T
      • getRrpcInterface(Class<T>,Object) returns T
      • getRrpcInterface(Class<T>,Object,Serializer,Parser) returns T

    Two basic types of remote interfaces are provided:

    • @Remote-annotated interfaces. These can be defined against arbitrary external REST resources.
    • RPC-over-REST interfaces. These are Java interfaces that allow you to make method calls on server-side POJOs.

    Refer to the following documentation on both flavors:

    • Overview > juneau-rest-client > REST Proxies
    • Overview > juneau-rest-server > REST/RPC

    • Overview > juneau-rest-client

        public static final String RESTCLIENT_debug
        Configuration property: Debug.
        Property:
        • ID: RESTCLIENT_debug
        • Name: "RestClient.debug.b"
        • Data type: boolean
        • System property: RestClient.debug
        • Environment variable: RESTCLIENT_DEBUG
        • Default: false
        • Methods:
          • RestClientBuilder.debug()
        Description:

        Enable debug mode.

        Has the following effects:

        • BeanContext.BEAN_debug is enabled.
        • RESTCLIENT_leakDetection is enabled.
        • RestClientBuilder.logToConsole() is called.

      • RESTCLIENT_executorService

        public static final String RESTCLIENT_executorService
        Configuration property: Executor service.
        Property:
        • ID: RESTCLIENT_executorService
        • Name: "RestClient.executorService.o"
        • Data type:
          • Class<? extends ExecutorService>
          • ExecutorService
        • Default: null.
        • Methods:
          • RestClientBuilder.executorService(ExecutorService, boolean)
        Description:

        Defines the executor service to use when calling future methods on the RestRequest class.

        This executor service is used to create Future objects on the following methods:

        • RestRequest.runFuture()

        The default executor service is a single-threaded ThreadPoolExecutor with a 30 second timeout and a queue size of 10.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • RESTCLIENT_leakDetection

        public static final String RESTCLIENT_leakDetection
        Configuration property: Enable leak detection.
        Property:
        • ID: RESTCLIENT_leakDetection
        • Name: "RestClient.leakDetection.b"
        • Data type: boolean
        • System property: RestClient.leakDetection
        • Environment variable: RESTCLIENT_LEAKDETECTION
        • Default: false
        • Methods:
          • RestClientBuilder.leakDetection()
          • RestClientBuilder.leakDetection(boolean)
        Description:

        Enable client and request/response leak detection.

        Causes messages to be logged to the console if clients or request/response objects are not properly closed when the finalize methods are invoked.

        Automatically enabled with RESTCLIENT_debug.

        Description:

        When set, relative URL strings passed in through the various rest call methods (e.g. get(Object) will be prefixed with the specified root.

      • hasContent

        protected boolean hasContent(String httpMethod)
        Returns true if specified http method has content.

        By default, anything not in this list can have content: GET, HEAD, DELETE, CONNECT, OPTIONS, TRACE.

        Parameters:
        httpMethod - The HTTP method. Must be upper-case.
        Returns:
        true if specified http method has content.

      • close

        public void close()
           throws IOException
        Calls Closeable.close() on the underlying CloseableHttpClient.

        It's good practice to call this method after the client is no longer used.

        Specified by:
        close in interface Closeable
        Specified by:
        close in interface AutoCloseable
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown by underlying stream.

      • closeQuietly

        public void closeQuietly()
        Same as close(), but ignores any exceptions.

      • execute

        protected HttpResponse execute(HttpHost target,
                               HttpRequestBase request,
                               HttpContext context)
                        throws ClientProtocolException,
                               IOException
        Execute the specified no-body request (e.g. GET/DELETE).

        Subclasses can override this method to provide specialized handling.

        Parameters:
        target - The target host for the request.
        Implementations may accept null if they can still determine a route, for example to a default target or by inspecting the request.
        request - The request to execute.
        context - The context to use for the execution, or null to use the default context.
        Returns:
        The response to the request.
        This is always a final response, never an intermediate response with an 1xx status code.
        Whether redirects or authentication challenges will be returned or handled automatically depends on the implementation and configuration of this client.
        Throws:
        IOException - In case of a problem or the connection was aborted.
        ClientProtocolException - In case of an http protocol error.

      • execute

        protected HttpResponse execute(HttpHost target,
                               HttpEntityEnclosingRequestBase request,
                               HttpContext context)
                        throws ClientProtocolException,
                               IOException
        Execute the specified body request (e.g. POST/PUT).

        Subclasses can override this method to provide specialized handling.

        Parameters:
        target - The target host for the request.
        Implementations may accept null if they can still determine a route, for example to a default target or by inspecting the request.
        request - The request to execute.
        context - The context to use for the execution, or null to use the default context.
        Returns:
        The response to the request.
        This is always a final response, never an intermediate response with an 1xx status code.
        Whether redirects or authentication challenges will be returned or handled automatically depends on the implementation and configuration of this client.
        Throws:
        IOException - In case of a problem or the connection was aborted.
        ClientProtocolException - In case of an http protocol error.

      • get

        public RestRequest get(Object url)
                throws RestCallException
        Perform a GET request against the specified URL.
        Parameters:
        url - The URL of the remote REST resource. Can be any of the following types:
        • URIBuilder
        • URI
        • URL
        • String
        • Object - Converted to String using toString()
        Returns:
        A RestRequest object that can be further tailored before executing the request and getting the response as a parsed object.
        Throws:
        RestCallException - If any authentication errors occurred.

      • put

        public RestRequest put(Object url,
                       Object body)
                throws RestCallException
        Perform a PUT request against the specified URL.
        Parameters:
        url - The URL of the remote REST resource. Can be any of the following types:
        • URIBuilder
        • URI
        • URL
        • String
        • Object - Converted to String using toString()
        body - The object to serialize and transmit to the URL as the body of the request. Can be of the following types:
        • Reader - Raw contents of Reader will be serialized to remote resource.
        • InputStream - Raw contents of InputStream will be serialized to remote resource.
        • ReaderResource - Raw contents of Reader will be serialized to remote resource. Additional headers and media type will be set on request.
        • StreamResource - Raw contents of InputStream will be serialized to remote resource. Additional headers and media type will be set on request.
        • Object - POJO to be converted to text using the Serializer registered with the RestClient.
        • HttpEntity - Bypass Juneau serialization and pass HttpEntity directly to HttpClient.
        • NameValuePairs - Converted to a URL-encoded FORM post.
        Returns:
        A RestRequest object that can be further tailored before executing the request and getting the response as a parsed object.
        Throws:
        RestCallException - If any authentication errors occurred.

      • callback

        public RestRequest callback(String callString)
                     throws RestCallException
        Performs a REST call where the entire call is specified in a simple string.

        This method is useful for performing callbacks when the target of a callback is passed in on an initial request, for example to signal when a long-running process has completed.

        The call string can be any of the following formats:

        • "[method] [url]" - e.g. "GET http://localhost/callback"
        • "[method] [url] [payload]" - e.g. "POST http://localhost/callback some text payload"
        • "[method] [headers] [url] [payload]" - e.g. "POST {'Content-Type':'text/json'} http://localhost/callback {'some':'json'}"

        The payload will always be sent using a simple StringEntity.

        Parameters:
        callString - The call string.
        Returns:
        A RestRequest object that can be further tailored before executing the request and getting the response as a parsed object.
        Throws:
        RestCallException - REST call failed.

      • request

        public RestRequest request(HttpMethod method,
                           Object url,
                           Object body)
                    throws RestCallException
        Perform a generic REST call.
        Parameters:
        method - The HTTP method.
        url - The URL of the remote REST resource. Can be any of the following types:
        • URIBuilder
        • URI
        • URL
        • String
        • Object - Converted to String using toString()
        body - The HTTP body content. Can be of the following types:
        • Reader - Raw contents of Reader will be serialized to remote resource.
        • InputStream - Raw contents of InputStream will be serialized to remote resource.
        • ReaderResource - Raw contents of Reader will be serialized to remote resource. Additional headers and media type will be set on request.
        • StreamResource - Raw contents of InputStream will be serialized to remote resource. Additional headers and media type will be set on request.
        • Object - POJO to be converted to text using the Serializer registered with the RestClient.
        • HttpEntity - Bypass Juneau serialization and pass HttpEntity directly to HttpClient.
        • NameValuePairs - Converted to a URL-encoded FORM post.
        This parameter is IGNORED if HttpMethod.hasContent() is false.
        Returns:
        A RestRequest object that can be further tailored before executing the request and getting the response as a parsed object.
        Throws:
        RestCallException - If any authentication errors occurred.

      • getRemote

        public <T> T getRemote(Class<T> interfaceClass)
        Create a new proxy interface against a 3rd-party REST interface.

        The URL to the REST interface is based on the following values:

        • The @Remote(path) annotation on the interface (remote-path).
        • The rootUrl on the client (root-url).
        • The fully-qualified class name of the interface (class-name).

        The URL calculation is as follows:

        • remote-path - If remote path is absolute.
        • root-url/remote-path - If remote path is relative and root-url has been specified.
        • root-url/class-name - If remote path is not specified.

        If the information is not available to resolve to an absolute URL, a RemoteMetadataException is thrown.

        Examples:

        package org.apache.foo; @RemoteResource(path="http://hostname/resturl/myinterface1") public interface MyInterface1 { ... } @RemoteResource(path="/myinterface2") public interface MyInterface2 { ... } public interface MyInterface3 { ... } // Resolves to "http://localhost/resturl/myinterface1" MyInterface1 i1 = RestClient .create() .build() .getRemote(MyInterface1.class); // Resolves to "http://hostname/resturl/myinterface2" MyInterface2 i2 = RestClient .create() .rootUrl("http://hostname/resturl") .build() .getRemote(MyInterface2.class); // Resolves to "http://hostname/resturl/org.apache.foo.MyInterface3" MyInterface3 i3 = RestClient .create() .rootUrl("http://hostname/resturl") .build() .getRemote(MyInterface3.class);

        • If you plan on using your proxy in a multi-threaded environment, you'll want to use an underlying pooling client connection manager.
        • Overview > juneau-rest-client > REST Proxies
        Parameters:
        interfaceClass - The interface to create a proxy for.
        Returns:
        The new proxy interface.
        Throws:
        RemoteMetadataException - If the REST URI cannot be determined based on the information given.

      • getRemote

        public <T> T getRemote(Class<T> interfaceClass,
                       Object restUrl)
        Same as getRemote(Class) except explicitly specifies the URL of the REST interface.
        • Overview > juneau-rest-client > REST Proxies

        The new proxy interface.

      • getRemote

        public <T> T getRemote(Class<T> interfaceClass,
                       Object restUrl,
                       Serializer serializer,
                       Parser parser)
        Same as getRemote(Class, Object) but allows you to override the serializer and parser used.

        Parameters:
        interfaceClass - The interface to create a proxy for.
        restUrl - The URL of the REST interface.
        serializer - The serializer used to serialize POJOs to the body of the HTTP request.
        parser - The parser used to parse POJOs from the body of the HTTP response.
        Returns:
        The new proxy interface.

      • getRrpcInterface

        public <T> T getRrpcInterface(Class<T> interfaceClass)
        Create a new Remote Interface against a @RemoteInterface-annotated class.

        Remote interfaces are interfaces exposed on the server side using either the RrpcServlet or RRPC REST methods.

        The URL to the REST interface is based on the following values:

        • The @Remote(path) annotation on the interface (remote-path).
        • The rootUrl on the client (root-url).
        • The fully-qualified class name of the interface (class-name).

        The URL calculation is as follows:

        • remote-path - If remote path is absolute.
        • root-url/remote-path - If remote path is relative and root-url has been specified.
        • root-url/class-name - If remote path is not specified.

        If the information is not available to resolve to an absolute URL, a RemoteMetadataException is thrown.

        • If you plan on using your proxy in a multi-threaded environment, you'll want to use an underlying pooling client connection manager.
        • Overview > juneau-rest-server > REST/RPC
        Parameters:
        interfaceClass - The interface to create a proxy for.
        Returns:
        The new proxy interface.
        Throws:
        RemoteMetadataException - If the REST URI cannot be determined based on the information given.

      • getRrpcInterface

        public <T> T getRrpcInterface(Class<T> interfaceClass,
                              Object restUrl)

        • Overview > juneau-rest-server > REST/RPC

      • execute

        public HttpResponse execute(HttpUriRequest request)
                     throws IOException,
                            ClientProtocolException
        Executes HTTP request using the default context.
        • This method gets passed on directly to the underlying HttpClient class.
        Specified by:
        execute in interface HttpClient
        Parameters:
        request - The request to execute.
        Returns:
        The response to the request.
        This is always a final response, never an intermediate response with an 1xx status code.
        Whether redirects or authentication challenges will be returned or handled automatically depends on the implementation and configuration of this client.
        Throws:
        IOException - In case of a problem or the connection was aborted.
        ClientProtocolException - In case of an http protocol error.

      • execute

        public HttpResponse execute(HttpHost target,
                            HttpRequest request,
                            HttpContext context)
                     throws IOException,
                            ClientProtocolException
        Executes HTTP request using the given context.
        • This method gets passed on directly to the underlying HttpClient class.
        • The execute(HttpHost,HttpEntityEnclosingRequestBase,HttpContext) and execute(HttpHost,HttpRequestBase,HttpContext) methods have been provided as wrappers around this method. Subclasses can override these methods for handling requests with and without bodies separately.
        • The RestCallHandler interface can also be implemented to intercept this method.
        Specified by:
        execute in interface HttpClient
        Parameters:
        target - The target host for the request.
        Implementations may accept null if they can still determine a route, for example to a default target or by inspecting the request.
        request - The request to execute.
        context - The context to use for the execution, or null to use the default context.
        Returns:
        The response to the request.
        This is always a final response, never an intermediate response with an 1xx status code.
        Whether redirects or authentication challenges will be returned or handled automatically depends on the implementation and configuration of this client.
        Throws:
        IOException - In case of a problem or the connection was aborted.
        ClientProtocolException - In case of an http protocol error.

      • execute

        public <T> T execute(HttpUriRequest request,
                     ResponseHandler<? extends T> responseHandler)
              throws IOException,
                     ClientProtocolException
        Executes HTTP request using the default context and processes the response using the given response handler.

        The content entity associated with the response is fully consumed and the underlying connection is released back to the connection manager automatically in all cases relieving individual ResponseHandlers from having to manage resource deallocation internally.

        • This method gets passed on directly to the underlying HttpClient class.
        Specified by:
        execute in interface HttpClient
        Parameters:
        request - The request to execute.
        responseHandler - The response handler.
        Returns:
        Object returned by response handler.
        Throws:
        IOException - In case of a problem or the connection was aborted.
        ClientProtocolException - In case of an http protocol error.
